div.h2: I am Ali, a PhD student in Computer Science. My research is focused on high-performance scientific computing under the supervision of Professor Marc Moreno Maza at the University of Western Ontario, Canada.

div.div:
My research interests are tied to cryptography and advanced software development with a strong background in mathematics, statistics, and programming. Currently, I am focused on developing high-performance software for computer algebra, that includes:
Computational algebraic geometry
Design and analysis of advanced data structures
Design patterns and analysis of parallel algorithms
Low-level programming for algebraic computation

My Ph.D. began with C implementation of algorithms over sparse multivariate polynomials from scratch in the Basic Polynomial Algebra Subprograms (BPAS) library. I am currently in charge of design, implementation, and optimization of algorithms over Finite Fields and Algebraic Extensions. This provides fast, optimized, and parallel (with multi-core/many-core supports) software for solving polynomial systems (e.g., Curves, Surfaces, and Lattices) with the theory of RegularChains.
Previously, I studied algorithmic efficiencies and new optimization of Fully Homomorphic Encryption over the integers with some experimental prototyping in SageMath (Python) as my master thesis under the supervision of RR. Farashahi. Prior to attending graduate school, I defended my bachelor technical report in applications of Elliptic Curve Cryptography schemes in SSH, TSL, and Bitcoin cryptocurrency protocols.
